criteria: Comparison of Product Size to Factor Size
descriptions: Student does not demonstrate any understanding of how multiplication affects the size of a number.
Student shows minimal understanding, struggling to identify if the product will be larger or smaller.
Student can sometimes identify if the product will be larger or smaller, but with frequent errors or requiring significant prompting.
Student can usually identify if the product will be larger or smaller based on the multiplier, but struggles with more complex scenarios (e.g., fractions less than 1).
Student consistently and accurately identifies if the product will be larger or smaller based on the multiplier, including fractions less than 1.
Student provides a clear and thorough explanation of why the product is larger or smaller, demonstrating a deep understanding of scaling.
Student cannot compare the size of the product to the size of the original factor.
Student attempts to compare sizes but demonstrates a misunderstanding of the relationship.
Student can sometimes compare sizes correctly but struggles to articulate the relationship or explain their reasoning.
Student generally compares sizes correctly and provides a basic explanation of the relationship.
Student accurately compares sizes and provides a clear explanation of the relationship, using appropriate mathematical vocabulary.
Student provides insightful comparisons and demonstrates a nuanced understanding of how the multiplier affects the scale of the original factor. Able to use multiple strategies to check answers.
Student cannot apply the concept of scaling to solve real-world problems.
Student struggles to apply the concept of scaling to real-world problems, even with significant guidance.
Student can sometimes apply the concept of scaling to real-world problems but makes frequent errors.
Student can apply the concept of scaling to solve simple real-world problems.
Student can apply the concept of scaling to solve a variety of real-world problems accurately.
Student can apply the concept of scaling to solve complex real-world problems and explain the implications of the scaling factor in the context of the problem.
